Find the determinant of a given matrix.
[1 8 3]
[2 7 9]
[5 1 6]

To find the determinant of a 3x3 matrix, you can use the rule of Sarrus or the cofactor expansion method. Let's use the cofactor expansion method for the given matrix:

\[
\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 8 & 3 \\
2 & 7 & 9 \\
5 & 1 & 6 \\
\end{bmatrix}
\]

The determinant of this matrix (\(A\)) is given by:

\[
\text{det}(A) = a(ei-fh) - b(di-fg) + c(dh-eg)
\]

where:

\[
A = \begin{bmatrix}
a & b & c \\
d & e & f \\
g & h & i \\
\end{bmatrix}
\]

In our case:

\[
a = 1, \, b = 8, \, c = 3, \, d = 2, \, e = 7, \, f = 9, \, g = 5, \, h = 1, \, i = 6
\]

Plugging these into the formula:

\[
\text{det}(A) = 1(7 \cdot 6 - 9 \cdot 1) - 8(2 \cdot 6 - 9 \cdot 5) + 3(2 \cdot 1 - 7 \cdot 5)
\]

Calculating each term:

- \(7 \cdot 6 - 9 \cdot 1 = 42 - 9 = 33\)
- \(2 \cdot 6 - 9 \cdot 5 = 12 - 45 = -33\)
- \(2 \cdot 1 - 7 \cdot 5 = 2 - 35 = -33\)

So:

\[
\text{det}(A) = 1 \cdot 33 - 8 \cdot (-33) + 3 \cdot (-33)
\]

Simplifying:

\[
\text{det}(A) = 33 + 264 - 99
\]

\[
\text{det}(A) = 198
\]

Therefore, the determinant of the matrix is \(198\).
